title: Between 1 January 2018 and 31 December 2018, will an armed group from South Sudan engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in South Sudan?

Several concerning factors lead me to think that the chances that more than 1,000 could be systematically killed in South Sudan over the course of this calendar year.  First, the US government and indeed US based NGOs or interest groups generally, are so involved in domestic problems that it is unlikely that any African country will be the subject of any consideration during 2018.  Secondly, the African Union and European Union will therefore be the major players.  Paul Kagame of Rwanda is the 2018 chairman of the AU Assembly and he is a man who would like to earn respect from his fellow African leaders.  The Kenyans and Ethiopians would no doubt prefer to slow the tide of refugees.   The EU has the same motivation.  At the same time, if we look at other states in the region with endemic civil war (Congo for example), it appears that lack of central government control and severe drought have led the FEWS to predict famine at level 5 through May in parts of the country.  The COH from December is not holding and conditions on the ground appear to be highly unstable.  The real question here is will a systematic, fatal attack on 1,000 civilians be made.  I have little doubt that many more than that will die of famine in this time period.  FEWS suggests that only sustained humanitarian aid will prevent that from happening.  My yes may be too strong because I have worked a bit with refugees from South Sudan and they have expressed profound fear of ongoing violence.  Even the local Kenyans have withdrawn back from the SS border because their cattle have been stolen and they are starving.

Factors + probability
The combination of famine and previous failed ceasefires increases the probability.  Oil profits rolled into militias and oil prices are increasing.
Factors - probability
The US cut support. UN brokered deals resulting in child soldier release (so some local confidence building).
This kind of mass action is winding down in these areas. At least, to the extent of this magnitude.

Cease fires have not held up for a significant length of time in South Sudans short history.  The current cease fire seems unlikely to hold as there are reports of the government using oil wealth to rearm and fund armed groups. A series of clashes have occurred already this year and without an apparent route to reestablish peace I think it unlikely that tensions will calm. Furthermore, FEWSNET has is not classifying more areas of South Sudan as Phase 4, conflict makes famine worse and vice versa. Attacks on UN and other humanitarian relief organisations have been frequent in the last year and it is likely that famine will be used as a weapon attacking civilians. The risk of famine also explains the increase in incidences of cattle raiding, it is likely that this will only increase sparking more conflict as the food supply worsens.

A peace agreement was reached in December of last year and it appears to be holding. While there are recent concerns about famine and use of oil to fund the civil war, as of yet, these don't seem to cause any one or the other to break the agreement. While unlikely, as US or UK led arms embargo will help in the peace process, however, there doesn't appear to be any forward progress on this front.

The war seems to have devolved into a nasty ethnic conflict will all parties committing atrocities. The only limiting factor seems to be limited organizational capacity--the parties can't organize large campaigns so most massacres are relatively small-scale. A campaign by somebody that produces more than 1,000 civilian deaths seems likely however, given the repeated failures to establish a ceasefire or bring the conflict to an end.
within a nation in the midst of a civil war, the likelihood that civilians are targeted as a means to instill fear in the population is great.

Conflict has been a hallmark of South Sudan since its gain of independence in 2005. The civil war in the Early to mid-2010s killed well over a million South Sudanese, and although the war has ended there is still a major presence of militant groups, including the Lord's Resistance Army. Though there is always a chance for conflict, and there will inevitably be deaths as a result, the likelihood of 1000 plus deaths seems low. That being said, given the fragility of South Sudan's current political situation, there is a resting chance of the breakout of organized or mass conflict.

Because I joined the question a month after it was posted, and I have the opportunity to see that in that month over 580 people have been killed in south sudan, it brings the percentage of 1001 people being killed in eleven months extremely likely. Also, our armed forces are sending more troops and that would increase the possibility.

South Sudan's civil war has caused civilian casualties meeting EWP definitions in 5 of the 7 years of its existence.  Although the base rate for all North African countries experiencing armed conflict/civil war is significantly lower (at 8.3% over 15 years) than South Sudan's (71.4% over 7 years) the dire situation on the ground in South Sudan explains the country's outlyer status.   In spite of increasing international pressure in the form of more sanctions and tightening arms embargoes, the conflict does not appear to be moving toward resolution.  There are still widespread food shortages causing severe hunger in the majority of the population.  Most armed groups are using this food insecurity as leverage and a weapon in itself.  Additionally, the factions among the belligerent groups continue to shift making peaceful resolution less likely. Given the high likelihood that conditions (economic and political) will deteriorate in 2018, there is little reason to hope that this year will see a resolution or calming of the conflict.  Therefore I project the likelihood of systemic violence causing over 1000 civilian casualties in South Sudan to be ~71% this year.

The prospect for over 1,000 deaths seems less probable by that date, however, the amount of deaths could rise from now until April when the Rain Season starts and violence typically lessens. It is unlikely that even with rebel and non government affiliated groups imcreasing that deaths will increase over that amount due to the criteria posed in the question. It is possible that as more cease fires fail, more civilians will die as a result, but it is hard to register these deaths as the government has an interest in recieving aid and could be less than transparent with these numbers.
Out of all African countries the SOuth Sudan might be the most vulnerable of the lot. Much of these atrocities might not be registered as such though so underestimation is likely

The ceasefire negotiations have been violated multiple times and ultimately has failed, with each rival ethnic group blaming the other. There seems to be no realistic move towards peace. With attacks on humanitarian workers, the international community may begin to reconsider it's efforts in response to the rising violence in South Sudan. If the international community reduces it's humanitarian efforts in an attempt to protect it's civilians (which is highly likely), violence will rise, raising the probability of systematic killings of civilians. Additionally, as long as Salvir Kiir is president, violence will continue and ethnic divisions will continue to influence systematic killings to send a message to his opposers.

No one doubts the diligence of South Sudanese in killing one another, but the stated criterion for this Q is rather narrow, so it is difficult for any one group to make the numbers.

Large campaigns that result in this many deaths each are relatively rare in the region. Neither side has that kind of killing power. Sadly, I do predict many thousands of innocent people will die, just by the dozens and by the hundreds in countless horrific incidents.

The amount of civilian deaths is very high for the disorganized groups operating in South Sudan. Civilian casualties will continue to occur and be target against both domestic and foreigners, but the numbers will be lower than 1,000.
Anticipate continued conflict and civilian deaths but not 1,000 deaths.
